inlineContent.text: This controller will setup a
as the main
keyboard view by default, but you can replace the view with
a custom view by overriding
and
call any
function with any custom view. Just
make sure to use the controller-based setup function if the
view must refer to the controller, since it uses an unowned
reference to avoid memory leaks that easily happen when the
view has a strong reference to the controller.
With KeyboardKit, inherit this class instead of the regular
to extend the controller with a lot
of additional features, properties, services etc.
Regarding the view controller lifecycle, there are some new
functions that you can override. These should be overridden
to assure that the keyboard is kept in sync:
is called when the controller
needs to setup or recreate the keyboard view. Override this
and call
to setup your main keyboard view.
is called when a text change is
used to trigger an autocomplete operation. By default, this
makes the controller call the
with
the
s
, if any.
is called when the text selection
changes, e.g. when moving the cursor. By default, it resets
the
The controller will by default use a
, so
you don’t have to override
when
you just want to use the standard keyboard.
This class provides you with many observable properties for
observing the keyboard’s global state:
provides autocomplete information
provides callout state and information
provides keyboard-specific information
provides feedback settings
provides keyboard text information
These contexts are injected as environment objects into the
root view and can be accessed anywhere in the hierarchy.
This class also provides you with services that you can use
to build more powerful keyboards:
is used to get autocomplete suggestions
is used to get callout actions
is used to get input characters for the keyboard layout
is used to handle keyboard actions
is used to determine the keyboard design
is used to determine the keyboard behavior
is used to handle autio & haptic feedback
is used to get a keyboard layout
You can replace any of these to customize how your keyboard
extension behaves.

abstract.text: The action handler that will be used by the keyboard to
handle keyboard actions.
Perform an autocomplete operation.
Insert the provided text.
The default, observable feedback settings.
This observable class can be used to observe the state of a
keyboard extension.
The default, observable dictation context.
This enum contains all keyboard types that can currently be
bound to the
switch keyboard action.
This protocol can be implemented by any type that can check
state state of keyboard extensions.
The appearance that is used to customize the keyboard’s
design, such as its colors, fonts etc.

, if

This class extends
with KeyboardKit
specific functionality.
This protocol can be used to specify behavior rules for the
keyboard. It aims to separate behavior from action handling
to make the code cleaner and more understandable.
This function is called whenever this controller should
try to stop dictation after returning from the main app.
Select the next locale, if any.
This class is used as global state for next keyboard button
views, since they need an input view controller to function.
The feedback handler that is used to trigger haptic and
audio feedback.
Delete backwards a certain number of times.
The callout action provider that is used to provide the
keyboard with secondary callout actions.
This preview controller can be used in SwiftUI previews.
This label can be used to show different views depending on
a provided enabled state.
This keyboard can be used to create alphabetic, numeric and
symbolic keyboards that mimic the native iOS keyboard.
This class provides keyboard extensions with contextual and
observable information about the text in the document proxy.
This class defines how a standard, Western keyboard behaves.
This enum defines all supported auto-capitalization types.
This protocol is used to make using the keyboard input view
controller more abstract and available to more platforms.
Get the bundle ID of the host app, which is the current
app that is using the keyboard.
This button makes any view behave as a next keyboard button,
which switches to the next keyboard when tapped and opens a
keyboard switcher menu when pressed.
This function is called whenever the keyboard view must
be created or updated.
The input set provider that is used to define the input
keys of the keyboard.
Perform a text context sync.
This behavior can be used to define a behavior that doesn’t
cause any changes to the keyboard when typing.

The default, observable keyboard context.
A custom text input proxy to which text can be routed.

complete set of keys and their layout.

KeyboardKit helps you build custom keyboards with Swift and SwiftUI.
This class provides keyboard extensions with contextual and
observable information about the keyboard extension itself.
